mdn.title: Subgrid
mdn.summary: The CSS grid layout module includes a subgrid value for grid-template-columns and grid-template-rows. This guide details what subgrid does and gives some use cases and design patterns that the feature solves.

example.codeHighlighted: .wrapper { display: grid; grid-template-columns: 1fr 1fr; } .item { grid-row: 1 / 4; display: grid; grid-template-rows: subgrid; }

webFeature.description_html: The subgrid value for the grid-template-columns and grid-template-rows properties allows a grid item to inherit the grid definition of its parent grid container.
webFeature.name: Subgrid

mdn.title: CSS writing modes
mdn.summary: The CSS writing modes module defines various international writing modes, such as left-to-right (e.g., used by Latin and Indic scripts), right-to-left (e.g., used by Hebrew or Arabic scripts), bidirectional (used when mixing left-to-right and right-to-left scripts), and vertical (e.g., used by some Asian scripts).

example.codeHighlighted: .vertical-text { writing-mode: vertical-lr; }

webFeature.description_html: The writing-mode CSS property sets whether text is laid out horizontally or vertically, and left to right, or right to left.
webFeature.name: writing-mode

mdn.title: CSS logical properties and values
mdn.summary: The CSS logical properties and values module defines logical properties and values that can control layout through logical rather than physical direction and dimension mappings. Logical properties define direction‐relative equivalents to their corresponding physical properties.

example.codeHighlighted: section { border-block: 8px solid blue; border-inline: 8px solid green; }

webFeature.description_html: CSS logical properties control borders, size, margin, and padding with directions and dimensions relative to the writing mode. For example, in a left to right, top to bottom writing mode, block-end refers to the bottom. Also known as flow relative.
webFeature.name: Logical properties

mdn.title: aspect-ratio
mdn.summary: The aspect-ratio CSS property allows you to define the desired width-to-height ratio of an element's box. This means that even if the parent container or viewport size changes, the browser will adjust the element's dimensions to maintain the specified width-to-height ratio. The specified aspect ratio is used in the calculation of auto sizes and some other layout functions.

example.codeHighlighted: .square { aspect-ratio: 1 / 1; }

webFeature.description_html: The aspect-ratio CSS property controls the width-to-height ratio of elements. For <img> and <video> elements, the width and height attributes used together with height: auto control the aspect ratio while the image/video is loading.
webFeature.name: aspect-ratio

entity.name: Viewport-Relative Units
entity.descriptionClean: lvh / lvw / lvmin / lvmax, sv*, dv*, etc.

mdn.title: <length>
mdn.summary: The <length> CSS data type represents a distance value. Lengths can be used in numerous CSS properties, such as width, height, margin, padding, border-width, font-size, and text-shadow.

example.codeHighlighted: body { height: 100dvh; }

resources.title: The large, small, and dynamic viewport units

webFeature.description_html: The sv*, lv*, and dv* CSS viewport units are relative to the smallest, largest, and current (dynamic) viewport size. They are used to size elements in relation to the viewport's dimensions.
webFeature.name: Small, large, and dynamic viewport units

example.codeHighlighted: @media (400px < width < 1000px) { /* ... */ }

webFeature.description_html: The range syntax of CSS media queries allows you to use mathematical comparison operators such as <, >, <=, and >= to define a range of values for a media query. For example, (400px < width < 1000px) returns true if the viewport width is between 400px and 1000px.
webFeature.name: Media query range syntax

mdn.title: CSS anchor positioning
mdn.summary: The CSS anchor positioning module defines features that allow you to tether elements together. Certain elements are defined as anchor elements; anchor-positioned elements can then have their size and position set based on the size and location of the anchor elements to which they are bound.

example.codeHighlighted: .anchor { anchor-name: --my-anchor; } .target { position: absolute; position-anchor: --my-anchor; position-area: start end; }

resources.title: Tether elements to each other with CSS anchor positioning

webFeature.description_html: Anchor positioning places an element based on the position of another element. For example, you can place a tooltip next to the content it references.
webFeature.name: Anchor positioning

mdn.title: CSS container queries
mdn.summary: Container queries enable you to apply styles to an element based on certain attributes of its container:

example.codeHighlighted: @container (min-width: 700px) { .card { display: grid; grid-template-columns: 2fr 1fr; } }

webFeature.description_html: Container size queries with the @container at-rule apply styles to an element based on the dimensions of its container.
webFeature.name: Container queries

mdn.title: Using container size and style queries
mdn.summary: Container queries enable you to apply styles to elements nested within a specific container based on the features of that container. The query returns true or false depending on whether the query condition is true for the container.

example.codeHighlighted: @container style(--fontColor: green) { /* <stylesheet> */ }

webFeature.description_html: Container style queries with the @container at-rule apply styles to an element based on the values of custom properties of its container.
webFeature.name: Container style queries

example.codeHighlighted: .element { height: 0; overflow: hidden; transition: height 0.3s; } .element.open { height: calc-size(auto); }

resources.title: CSS interpolate-size property and calc-size() function

webFeature.description_html: The calc-size() CSS function computes mathematical expressions that include height and width keyword values, for example calc-size(fit-content, size / 2). Not to be confused with the calc() CSS function, which cannot use keyword values.
webFeature.name: calc-size()

mdn.title: <blend-mode>
mdn.summary: The <blend-mode> CSS data type describes how colors should appear when elements overlap. It is used in the background-blend-mode and mix-blend-mode properties.

example.codeHighlighted: .item2 { color: #000; mix-blend-mode: overlay; }

webFeature.description_html: The mix-blend-mode CSS property blends an element's content with its background or parent elements using blend modes like multiply, difference, or color.
webFeature.name: mix-blend-mode

mdn.title: backdrop-filter
mdn.summary: The backdrop-filter CSS property lets you apply graphical effects such as blurring or color shifting to the area behind an element. Because it applies to everything behind the element, to see the effect the element or its background needs to be transparent or partially transparent.

example.codeHighlighted: .box { backdrop-filter: blur(10px); }

webFeature.description_html: The backdrop-filter CSS property applies graphical effects such as blurring or color shifting to the area behind an element.
webFeature.name: backdrop-filter

mdn.title: <easing-function>
mdn.summary: The <easing-function> CSS data type represents a mathematical function that describes the rate at which a value changes.

example.codeHighlighted: :root { --bounce-easing: linear( 0, 0.063, 0.25 18.2%, 1 36.4%, 0.813, 0.75, 0.813, 1, 0.938, 1, 1 ); }

webFeature.description_html: The linear() easing function for animations and transitions interpolates linearly between the control points, and can be used to approximate complex easing functions, such as a bounce effect.
webFeature.name: linear() easing

mdn.title: min-content
mdn.summary: The min-content sizing keyword represents the minimum intrinsic size of the content. For text content this means that the content will take all soft-wrapping opportunities, becoming as small as the longest word.

example.codeHighlighted: h2 { width: max-content; }

webFeature.description_html: The min-content and max-content CSS keywords represent the smallest and largest intrinsic sizes of an element.
webFeature.name: min-content and max-content

mdn.title: conic-gradient()
mdn.summary: The conic-gradient() CSS function creates an image consisting of a gradient with color transitions rotated around a center point (rather than radiating from the center). Example conic gradients include pie charts and color wheels. The result of the conic-gradient() function is an object of the <gradient> data type, which is a special kind of <image>.

example.codeHighlighted: .blue-to-red { background: conic-gradient(from 45deg, blue, red); }

webFeature.description_html: The conic-gradient() and repeating-conic-gradient() CSS functions create backgrounds that progress between two or more colors around a center point.
webFeature.name: Conic gradients

mdn.title: offset-path
mdn.summary: The offset-path CSS property specifies a path for an element to follow and determines the element's positioning within the path's parent container or the SVG coordinate system. The path is a line, a curve, or a geometrical shape along which the element gets positioned or moves.

example.codeHighlighted: .blueBox { background-color: blue; offset-path: border-box; offset-distance: 5%; }

webFeature.description_html: The offset CSS property animates an element along a defined motion path.
webFeature.name: Motion path

mdn.title: shape()
mdn.summary: The shape() CSS function is used to define a shape for the clip-path and offset-path properties. It combines an initial starting point with a series of shape commands that define the path of the shape. The shape() function is a member of the <basic-shape> data type.

example.codeHighlighted: .clipped { clip-path: shape( from top left, hline to 100%, vline to 100%, curve to 0% 100% with 50% 0%, ); }

mdn.title: color()
mdn.summary: The color() functional notation allows a color to be specified in a particular, specified color space rather than the implicit sRGB color space that most of the other color functions operate in.

example.codeHighlighted: .brightest-green { background: color(display-p3 0 1 0); }

webFeature.description_html: The color() function picks a color from a given color space. Wide gamut color spaces like display-p3 allow showing more vibrant and saturated colors than the standard srgb color space.
webFeature.name: color()

mdn.title: accent-color
mdn.summary: The accent-color CSS property sets the accent color for user-interface controls generated by some elements.

example.codeHighlighted: input[type='checkbox'] { accent-color: tomato; }

webFeature.description_html: The accent-color CSS property sets a color for checkboxes, radio buttons, and other form controls.
webFeature.name: accent-color

mdn.title: color-mix()
mdn.summary: The color-mix() functional notation takes two <color> values and returns the result of mixing them in a given colorspace by a given amount.

example.codeHighlighted: .teal { background: color-mix(in lab, white 20%, #34c9eb); }

webFeature.description_html: The color-mix() function mixes two colors in a given color space and by a given amount. Commonly, lighter or darker variations of a color are created by mixing with white or black.
webFeature.name: color-mix()

mdn.title: lch()
mdn.summary: The lch() functional notation expresses a given color using the LCH color space, which represents lightness, chroma, and hue. It uses the same L axis as the lab() color function of the CIELab color space, but it uses the polar coordinates C (Chroma) and H (Hue).

example.codeHighlighted: .foo { background-color: lab(29.2345% 39.3825 20.0664); background-color: lch(29.2345% 44.2 27); }

webFeature.description_html: The Oklab color space expresses colors in terms of lightness and how red/green and blue/yellow a color is, aiming to match how humans perceive colors. Oklch is a variant of Oklab with polar coordinates. These color spaces can be used with the CSS color(), oklab(), and oklch() functions.
webFeature.name: Oklab and Oklch

example.codeHighlighted: .foo { --color: #4488dd; background-color: hsl(from var(--color) h s calc(l * 1.2)) }

resources.title: Create a color theme with CSS Relative Color Syntax, CSS color-mix(), and CSS color-contrast()

webFeature.description_html: The from keyword for color functions (color(), hsl(), oklch(), etc.) creates a new color based on a given color by modifying the values of the input color. Also known as relative color syntax (RCS).
webFeature.name: Relative colors

example.codeHighlighted: .gradient { background: linear-gradient(in oklab, hsl(80 90% 50%), red); }

resources.title: Using Different Color Spaces for Non-Boring Gradients

webFeature.description_html: Gradient interpolation controls how the colors between gradient stops are calculated in CSS. For example, linear-gradient(to right in oklch longer hue, red, red); calculates in the oklch color space, with the hue going all the way around the hue circle from red back to red.
webFeature.name: Gradient interpolation

mdn.title: color-scheme
mdn.summary: The color-scheme CSS property allows an element to indicate which color schemes it can comfortably be rendered in. User agents change the following aspects of the UI chrome to match the used color scheme:

example.codeHighlighted: .foo { color-scheme: light dark; }

webFeature.description_html: The color-scheme CSS property sets which color schemes (light or dark) an element uses and may prevent automatic dark mode adjustments by the browser.
webFeature.name: color-scheme

mdn.title: light-dark()
mdn.summary:
The light-dark() CSS <color> function enables setting two colors for a property - returning one of the two colors options by detecting if the developer has set a light or dark color scheme or the user has requested light or dark color theme - without needing to encase the theme colors within a prefers-color-scheme media feature query.
Users are able to indicate their color-scheme preference through their operating system settings (e.g., light or dark mode) or their user agent settings. The light-dark() function enables providing two color values where any <color> value is accepted. The light-dark() CSS color function returns the first value if the user's preference is set to light or if no preference is set and the second value if the user's preference is set to dark.

example.codeHighlighted: code { color: light-dark(black, white); }

webFeature.description_html: The light-dark() CSS function accepts two colors and uses one depending on the current color scheme.
webFeature.name: light-dark()

mdn.title: CSS scroll snap
mdn.summary: The CSS scroll snap module provides properties that let you control the panning and scrolling behavior by defining snap positions. Content can be snapped into position as the user scrolls overflowing content within a scroll container, providing paging and scroll positioning.

example.codeHighlighted: .scroller { height: 300px; overflow-y: scroll; scroll-snap-type: y mandatory; } .scroller section { scroll-snap-align: start; }

webFeature.description_html: CSS scroll snap controls the panning and scrolling behavior within a scroll container.
webFeature.name: Scroll snap

mdn.title: overscroll-behavior
mdn.summary: The overscroll-behavior CSS property sets what a browser does when reaching the boundary of a scrolling area.

example.codeHighlighted: .foo { height: 200px; overflow: auto; overscroll-behavior-y: contain; }

webFeature.description_html: The overscroll-behavior CSS property disables default scrolling behaviors when the edges of a scrolling area are reached.
webFeature.name: overscroll-behavior

mdn.title: scroll-behavior
mdn.summary: The scroll-behavior CSS property sets the behavior for a scrolling box when scrolling is triggered by the navigation or CSSOM scrolling APIs.

example.codeHighlighted: .foo { scroll-behavior: auto; scroll-behavior: smooth; }

webFeature.description_html: The scroll-behavior CSS property controls whether scrolling is smooth or snaps, for scroll actions not performed by the user such as those triggered by navigation.
webFeature.name: scroll-behavior

mdn.title: scrollbar-gutter
mdn.summary: The scrollbar-gutter CSS property allows authors to reserve space for the scrollbar, preventing unwanted layout changes as the content grows while also avoiding unnecessary visuals when scrolling isn't needed.

example.codeHighlighted: .container { scrollbar-gutter: stable; }

webFeature.description_html: The scrollbar-gutter CSS property reserves space for the scrollbar, preventing unwanted layout changes as the scrollbar appears and disappears.
webFeature.name: scrollbar-gutter

mdn.title: View Transition API
mdn.summary: The View Transition API provides a mechanism for easily creating animated transitions between different website views. This includes animating between DOM states in a single-page app (SPA), and animating the navigation between documents in a multi-page app (MPA).

resources.title: Smooth and simple transitions with the View Transitions API

webFeature.description_html: The @view-transition CSS rule sets whether a document opts-in to transitions between documents in a multi-page application. Both the old and new document must opt-in for a transition to be triggered.
webFeature.name: Cross-document view transitions

mdn.title: CSS scroll-driven animations
mdn.summary: The CSS scroll-driven animations module provides functionality that builds on top of the CSS animations module and Web Animations API. It allows you to animate property values based on a progression along a scroll-based timeline instead of the default time-based document timeline. This means that you can animate an element by scrolling a scrollable element, rather than just by the passing of time.

example.codeHighlighted: html { scroll-timeline: --page-scroll block; } @keyframes grow-progress { from { transform: scaleX(0); } to { transform: scaleX(1); } } #progress { animation: grow-progress auto linear; animation-timeline: --page-scroll; }

resources.title: Unleash the Power of Scroll-Driven Animations
Animate elements on scroll with Scroll-driven animations

webFeature.description_html: The animation-timeline, scroll-timeline, and view-timeline CSS properties advance animations based on the user's scroll position.
webFeature.name: Scroll-driven animations

entity.name: Discrete Properties Animations
entity.description: Animate to and from properties such as `display: none`
entity.descriptionClean: Animate to and from properties such as display: none
entity.descriptionHtml: Animate to and from properties such as display: none

example.codeHighlighted: /* IS-OPEN STATE */ dialog[open] { translate: 0 0; } /* EXIT STATE */ dialog { transition: opacity 1s, display 1s allow-discrete, overlay 1s allow-discrete; translate: 0 100vh; } /* 0. BEFORE-OPEN STATE */ @starting-style { dialog[open] { translate: 0 100vh; } }

webFeature.description_html: The transition-behavior: allow-discrete CSS declaration allows transitions for properties whose animation behavior is discrete. Such properties can't be interpolated and swap from their start value to the end value at 50%.
webFeature.name: transition-behavior

mdn.title: Using container scroll-state queries
mdn.summary: Container scroll-state queries are a type of container query. Rather than selectively applying styles to descendant elements based on the container's size, scroll-state queries allow you to selectively apply styles to descendant elements based on the container's scroll state. This can include whether the container is partially scrolled, snapped to a scroll snap container ancestor, or positioned via position: sticky and stuck to a boundary of a scroll container ancestor.

example.codeHighlighted: @container scroller scroll-state(scrollable: top) { .back-to-top { translate: 0 0; } }

webFeature.description_html: Container scroll-state queries with the @container scroll-state(...) at-rule apply styles to an element based on the sticky positioning, snapped, and scrollable state of the container.
webFeature.name: Container scroll-state queries

mdn.title: Creating CSS carousels
mdn.summary: The CSS overflow module defines features enabling the creation of flexible and accessible pure-CSS carousels with browser-generated and developer-styled scroll buttons and scroll markers. This guide explains how to create a carousel using these features.

example.codeHighlighted: .carousel { &::scroll-button(left) { content: "⬅" / "Scroll Left"; } &::scroll-button(right) { content: "⮕" / "Scroll Right"; } &::scroll-button(*):focus-visible { outline-offset: 5px; } }

webFeature.description_html: A scroll container can be navigated by activating ::scroll-marker pseudo-elements which appear in a generated ::scroll-marker-group pseudo-element, either before or after the scroll container.
webFeature.name: Scroll markers

mdn.title: line-clamp
mdn.summary: The line-clamp CSS property allows limiting of the contents of a block to the specified number of lines.

example.codeHighlighted: p { display: -webkit-box; -webkit-line-clamp: 2; -webkit-box-orient: vertical; overflow: hidden; }

webFeature.description_html: The line-clamp CSS property limits the text in a block container to a certain number of lines. The prefixed -webkit-line-clamp is widely supported but only works with -webkit-box-orient: vertical in combination with display: -webkit-box or display: -webkit-inline-box.
webFeature.name: line-clamp

mdn.title: Variable fonts
mdn.summary: Variable fonts are an evolution of the OpenType font specification that enables many different variations of a typeface to be incorporated into a single file, rather than having a separate font file for every width, weight, or style. They let you access all the variations contained in a given font file via CSS and a single @font-face reference. This article will give you all you need to know to get you started using variable fonts.

example.codeHighlighted: @font-face { font-family: "Fraunces"; src: url("fraunces.woff2") format("woff2"); font-weight: 200 700; } h2 { font-family: "Fraunces"; font-variation-settings: "wght" 375, "SOFT" 100; }

webFeature.description_html: The font-variation-settings CSS property sets an "axis of variability" on a variable font, such as weight, optical size, or a custom axis defined by the typeface designer. When possible, use other CSS font properties, such as font-weight: bold. Also known as variable fonts.
webFeature.name: font-variation-settings

mdn.title: text-wrap
mdn.summary: The text-wrap CSS shorthand property controls how text inside an element is wrapped. The different values provide:

example.codeHighlighted: .balanced { max-inline-size: 50ch; text-wrap: balance; }

webFeature.description_html: The text-wrap: balance CSS declaration balances the length of each line when text is broken into multiple lines. Also known as headline balancing.
webFeature.name: text-wrap: balance

mdn.title: text-wrap
mdn.summary: The text-wrap CSS shorthand property controls how text inside an element is wrapped. The different values provide:

example.codeHighlighted: .pretty { text-wrap: pretty; }

webFeature.description_html: The text-wrap: pretty CSS declaration prioritizes better layout over speed when text is broken into multiple lines.
webFeature.name: text-wrap: pretty

mdn.title: hanging-punctuation
mdn.summary: The hanging-punctuation CSS property specifies whether a punctuation mark should hang at the start or end of a line of text. Hanging punctuation may be placed outside the line box.

example.codeHighlighted: p.hanging { hanging-punctuation: first last; }

webFeature.description_html: The hanging-punctuation CSS property puts punctuation characters outside of the box to align the text with the rest of the document.
webFeature.name: Hanging punctuation

mdn.title: initial-letter
mdn.summary: The initial-letter CSS property sets the size and sink for dropped, raised, and sunken initial letters. This property applies to ::first-letter pseudo-elements and inline-level first children of block containers.

example.codeHighlighted: .intro { /* Initial letter occupies 3 lines */ initial-letter: 3; }

webFeature.description_html: The initial-letter CSS property sets the number of lines the first letter of an element occupies. You can use the property to make a raised capital or drop cap.
webFeature.name: initial-letter

example.codeHighlighted: p { text-box-edge: cap alphabetic; text-box-trim: trim-both; }

resources.title: Leading-Trim: The Future of Digital Typesetting

mdn.title: CSS value functions
mdn.summary: CSS value functions are statements that invoke special data processing or calculations to return a CSS value for a CSS property. CSS value functions represent more complex data types and they may take some input arguments to calculate the return value.

example.codeHighlighted: .element { width: clamp(100px, 50vw, 600px); }

webFeature.description_html: The min() and max() CSS functions return the minimum or maximum of the arguments, while clamp() clamps a value to a given range.
webFeature.name: min(), max(), and clamp()

mdn.title: CSS value functions
mdn.summary: CSS value functions are statements that invoke special data processing or calculations to return a CSS value for a CSS property. CSS value functions represent more complex data types and they may take some input arguments to calculate the return value.

example.codeHighlighted: div { width: calc(100px * cos(45deg)); height: calc(100px * cos(45deg)); }

webFeature.description_html: The sin(), cos(), tan(), asin(), acos(), atan(), and atan2() CSS functions compute various trigonometric functions.
webFeature.name: sin(), cos(), tan(), asin(), acos(), atan(), and atan2() (CSS)

mdn.title: CSS value functions
mdn.summary: CSS value functions are statements that invoke special data processing or calculations to return a CSS value for a CSS property. CSS value functions represent more complex data types and they may take some input arguments to calculate the return value.

example.codeHighlighted: div { width: round(var(--width), 50px); line-height: mod(7, 2); /* 1 */ }

webFeature.description_html: The round(), mod(), and rem() CSS functions compute rounded values and the remainder after division.
webFeature.name: round(), mod(), and rem()

mdn.title: sign()
mdn.summary: The sign() CSS function contains one calculation, and returns -1 if the numeric value of the argument is negative, +1 if the numeric value of the argument is positive, 0⁺ if the numeric value of the argument is 0⁺, and 0⁻ if the numeric value of the argument is 0⁻.

example.codeHighlighted: div { top: sign(20vh - 100px); width: abs(20% - 100px); }

webFeature.description_html: The abs() and sign() CSS functions compute the absolute value or the sign of the input.
webFeature.name: abs() and sign()

mdn.title: pow()
mdn.summary: The pow() CSS function is an exponential function that returns the value of a base raised to the power of a number.

example.codeHighlighted: h1 { font-size: calc(1rem * pow(1.5, 4)); }

webFeature.description_html: The pow(), sqrt(), hypot(), log(), and exp() CSS functions compute various exponential functions.
webFeature.name: pow(), sqrt(), hypot(), log(), and exp()

mdn.title: @supports
mdn.summary:
The @supports CSS at-rule lets you specify CSS declarations that depend on a browser's support for CSS features.
Using this at-rule is commonly called a feature query.
The rule must be placed at the top level of your code or nested inside any other conditional group at-rule.

example.codeHighlighted: @supports (display: table-cell) and (display: list-item) { //... }

webFeature.description_html: The @supports at-rule applies styles based on a browser's support for CSS features, such as a CSS property and value. Also known as feature queries.
webFeature.name: @supports

mdn.title: @property
mdn.summary: The @property CSS at-rule is part of the CSS Houdini set of APIs. It allows developers to explicitly define CSS custom properties, allowing for property type checking and constraining, setting default values, and defining whether a custom property can inherit values or not.

example.codeHighlighted: @property --property-name { syntax: "<color>"; inherits: false; initial-value: #c0ffee; }

webFeature.description_html: The CSS.registerProperty() static method and the @property CSS at-rule register custom properties for which types and behaviors can be defined.
webFeature.name: Registered custom properties

mdn.title: :has()
mdn.summary: The functional :has() CSS pseudo-class represents an element if any of the relative selectors that are passed as an argument match at least one element when anchored against this element. This pseudo-class presents a way of selecting a parent element or a previous sibling element with respect to a reference element by taking a relative selector list as an argument.

example.codeHighlighted: a:has(> img) { border: 2px solid grey; }

webFeature.description_html: The :has() CSS functional pseudo-class matches an element if any of the selectors passed as parameters would match at least one element.
webFeature.name: :has()

mdn.title: :where()
mdn.summary: The :where() CSS pseudo-class function takes a selector list as its argument, and selects any element that can be selected by one of the selectors in that list.

example.codeHighlighted: :where(header, main, footer) p:hover { color: red; cursor: pointer; }

webFeature.description_html: The :where() CSS functional pseudo-class takes a selector list as its argument, and matches any element that can be selected by one of the selectors in that list. It is functionally equivalent to the selectors in the list, but doesn't affect the CSS rule specificity.
webFeature.name: :where()

mdn.title: @layer
mdn.summary: The @layer CSS at-rule is used to declare a cascade layer and can also be used to define the order of precedence in case of multiple cascade layers.

example.codeHighlighted: @layer layer-name {rules}

webFeature.description_html: The @layer CSS at-rule avoids specificity conflicts by providing priority levels for different groups of CSS rules, such as low-priority styles like resets, and high-priority styles like UI components.
webFeature.name: Cascade layers

mdn.title: CSS nesting
mdn.summary: The CSS nesting module defines a syntax for nesting selectors, providing the ability to nest one style rule inside another, with the selector of the child rule relative to the selector of the parent rule.

example.codeHighlighted: .parent { color: blue; .child { color: red; } }

webFeature.description_html: CSS nesting allows for shorter selectors, easier reading, and more modularity by nesting rules inside others.
webFeature.name: Nesting

mdn.title: image-set()
mdn.summary: The image-set() CSS functional notation is a method of letting the browser pick the most appropriate CSS image from a given set, primarily for high pixel density screens.

example.codeHighlighted: .box { background-image: image-set( url("small-balloons.jpg") 1x, url("large-balloons.jpg") 2x); }

webFeature.description_html: The image-set() CSS function provides a set of images at different resolutions or pixel densities, which the browser can pick from, depending on the device capabilities.
webFeature.name: image-set()

mdn.title: @scope
mdn.summary: The @scope CSS at-rule enables you to select elements in specific DOM subtrees, targeting elements precisely without writing overly-specific selectors that are hard to override, and without coupling your selectors too tightly to the DOM structure.

example.codeHighlighted: @scope (.card) { :scope { padding: 1rem; } .title { font-size: 1.2rem; } }

webFeature.description_html: The @scope CSS at-rule sets the scope for a group of rules.
webFeature.name: @scope

entity.name: `nth-child of S`
entity.description: Pre-filter a set of child elements before applying `nth-child` to it.
entity.descriptionClean: Pre-filter a set of child elements before applying nth-child to it.
entity.descriptionHtml: Pre-filter a set of child elements before applying nth-child to it.

example.codeHighlighted: :nth-child(2 of .highlight) border: 2px red solid; }

resources.title: More control over :nth-child() selections with the of S syntax

webFeature.description_html: The of syntax for the :nth-child() and :nth-last-child() CSS functional pseudo-classes match elements by the relative position of elements, counted from the first or last sibling matching a selector list.
webFeature.name: :nth-child() of <selector>

entity.name: `field-sizing`
entity.description: Allows form controls such as `<textarea>` to be sized based on their content.
entity.descriptionClean: Allows form controls such as <textarea> to be sized based on their content.
entity.descriptionHtml: Allows form controls such as <textarea> to be sized based on their content.

mdn.title: field-sizing
mdn.summary: The field-sizing CSS property enables you to control the sizing behavior of elements that are given a default preferred size, such as form control elements. This property enables you to override the default sizing behavior, allowing form controls to adjust in size to fit their contents.

example.codeHighlighted: input, textarea { field-sizing: content; min-width: 50px; max-width: 350px; }

webFeature.description_html: The field-sizing CSS property allows form controls such as <textarea> to be sized based on their content.
webFeature.name: field-sizing

entity.name: `::target-text`
entity.description: The `::target-text` pseudo-element allows you to style text highlighted by a URL text fragment such as `#:~:text=snippet`.
entity.descriptionClean: The ::target-text pseudo-element allows you to style text highlighted by a URL text fragment such as #:~:text=snippet.
entity.descriptionHtml: The ::target-text pseudo-element allows you to style text highlighted by a URL text fragment such as #:~:text=snippet.

mdn.title: ::target-text
mdn.summary: The ::target-text CSS pseudo-element represents the text that has been scrolled to if the browser supports text fragments. It allows authors to choose how to highlight that section of text.

webFeature.description_html: The ::target-text pseudo-element allows you to style text highlighted by a URL text fragment such as #:~:text=snippet.
webFeature.name: ::target-text

entity.name: `@function`
entity.description: The `@function` CSS at-rule defines a custom function that takes CSS values or custom properties as arguments, and returns a CSS value.
entity.descriptionClean: The @function CSS at-rule defines a custom function that takes CSS values or custom properties as arguments, and returns a CSS value.
entity.descriptionHtml: The @function CSS at-rule defines a custom function that takes CSS values or custom properties as arguments, and returns a CSS value.

example.codeHighlighted: @function --negate(--value) { result: calc(-1 * var(--value)); }

resources.title: CSS Custom Functions are coming … and they are going to be a game changer!

webFeature.description_html: The @function CSS at-rule defines a custom function that takes CSS values or custom properties as arguments, and returns a CSS value. It can be based on conditional logic such as by using the @media at-rule.
webFeature.name: @function

entity.name: `display: contents`
entity.description: Sets an element to display only its contents, not itself.
entity.descriptionClean: Sets an element to display only its contents, not itself.

webFeature.description_html: The display: contents CSS declaration sets an element to display only its contents, not itself.
webFeature.name: display: contents

entity.name: Advanced `attr()`
entity.description: Support for properties other than content
entity.descriptionClean: Support for properties other than content

example.codeHighlighted: .title { background-color: attr(data-color type(<color>)); }

resources.title: First Look at The Modern attr()

webFeature.description_html: The attr() CSS function, in the context of any property, returns the value of an attribute of an HTML element, with the option to return it as a specific type or unit. You can set a default value for missing or invalid attributes.
webFeature.name: attr()

entity.name: `if()`
entity.description: The `if()` CSS function is an inline conditional value that returns a value based on a set of conditions.
entity.descriptionClean: The if() CSS function is an inline conditional value that returns a value based on a set of conditions.
entity.descriptionHtml: The if() CSS function is an inline conditional value that returns a value based on a set of conditions.

example.codeHighlighted: div { color: var(--color); background-color: if(style(--color: white): black; else: white); }

webFeature.description_html: The if() CSS function is an inline conditional value that returns a value based on a set of conditions.
webFeature.name: if()

mdn.title: sibling-index()
mdn.summary: The sibling-index() CSS function returns an integer representing the position of the current element in the DOM tree relative to all its sibling elements. The returned value is the index number of the contextual child's position among all the sibling elements within a parent element, with the first child returning 1 and the last child, returning Element.children.length.

resources.title: Tree Counting Functions: the sibling-count() and sibling-index() notations

webFeature.description_html: The sibling-count() and sibling-index() CSS functions return integers that are useful to style elements based on their positions among siblings or on the number of siblings, for example as part of a calc() expression.
webFeature.name: sibling-count() and sibling-index()

mdn.title: sibling-count()
mdn.summary: The sibling-count() CSS function returns an integer representing the total number of direct child DOM elements of the parent element on which it is used.

resources.title: Tree Counting Functions: the sibling-count() and sibling-index() notations

webFeature.description_html: The sibling-count() and sibling-index() CSS functions return integers that are useful to style elements based on their positions among siblings or on the number of siblings, for example as part of a calc() expression.
webFeature.name: sibling-count() and sibling-index()
